elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Two cadmium-organic frameworks were synthesized, namely, [Cd(dptz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·{Cd[(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CS]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}·(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, dptz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,6-di-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine) and Cd(dpmtz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, dpmtz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,6-di-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2-dihydro-1-mercapto-1,2,4,5-tetrazine). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained by the self-assembly of dptz, Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and thiourea under solvothermal conditions. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was prepared through an in situ ligand reaction in which generated a new ligand dpmtz only by changing reaction temperature. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were characterized by single-crystal X-ray structure determination, thermogravimetric analysis and powder X-ray diffraction studies. The adsorption behavior shows that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has selective adsorption capacities of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Two cadmium-organic frameworks were synthesized, namely, [Cd(dptz)2]·{Cd[(NH2)2CS]4}·(NO3)4 (1, dptz=3,6-di-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine) and Cd(dpmtz)2 (2, dpmtz=3,6-di-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2-dihydro-1-mercapto-1,2,4,5-tetrazine). Compound 1 was obtained by the self-assembly of dptz, Cd(SPh)2 and thiourea under solvothermal conditions. Compound 2 was prepared through an in situ ligand reaction in which generated a new ligand dpmtz only by changing reaction temperature. Compound 1 and 2 were characterized by single-crystal X-ray structure determination, thermogravimetric analysis and powder X-ray diffraction studies. The adsorption behavior shows that compound 2 has selective adsorption capacities of CO2 over N2.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">By changing the reaction temperature, we synthesize and characterize compound Cd(dpmtz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> which shows selective adsorption behavior of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0025" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Two cadmium-organic frameworks were synthesized and structurally characterized.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">We found an in situ reaction in which a new ligand dpmtz was generated.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Cd(dpmtz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> shows selective adsorption behavior of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
By changing the reaction temperature, we synthesize and characterize compound Cd(dpmtz)2 which shows selective adsorption behavior of CO2 over N2.





Highlights



•
Two cadmium-organic frameworks were synthesized and structurally characterized.


•
We found an in situ reaction in which a new ligand dpmtz was generated.


•
Cd(dpmtz)2 shows selective adsorption behavior of CO2 over N2.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Two cadmium-organic frameworks were synthesized and structurally characterized.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">We found an in situ reaction in which a new ligand dpmtz was generated.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Cd(dpmtz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> shows selective adsorption behavior of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The rational design and construction of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention because of their potential applications in areas such as gas storage and separation . As we know, properties are inextricably linked with the natural structure. The properties can be subtly moderated by slight structure changes . The primary task for the synthesis of MOFs is to choose appropriate metal-connecting nodes and organic-bridging ligands to control the formation of the compounds with required structures and properties. Generally, long chain ligands can lead to large, suitable and well defined voids. Therefore, such ligands are regarded as excellent candidates for the construction of pore structures . For example, Biradha and co-workers reported a nickel compound formulated {[Ni(4,4′-bipyridine)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2pyrene}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> with a 2D network which possesses inner cavities of ca. 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å . By changing 4,4′-bipyridine to a longer ligand 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene, they obtained a nickel compound with bigger square dimensions of 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å . Moreover, according to some recent researches, the interaction between the localized dipoles of the N-containing group and the quadrupole moment of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> would induce the dispersion and electrostatic forces to enhance CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption and separation abilities on MOFs . Therefore, the long chain ligand 3,6-di-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine (dptz) which contains tetrazine and pyridine functional groups serves as a suitable candidate. The coordination chemistry for these compounds has been studied and some MOFs have been obtained . However, synthesis of robust open frameworks with both high porosity and thermal stability by using ligand (dptz) is scarce. As an extension of our investigation into the chemistry of N-containing heterocyclic MOFs , we used the ligand (dptz) as the bridging ligand to study the properties and the structures of MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Two cadmium-organic frameworks were synthesized and structurally characterized.
We found an in situ reaction in which a new ligand dpmtz was generated.
Cd(dpmtz)2 shows selective adsorption behavior of CO2 over N2.
The rational design and construction of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention because of their potential applications in areas such as gas storage and separation . As we know, properties are inextricably linked with the natural structure. The properties can be subtly moderated by slight structure changes . The primary task for the synthesis of MOFs is to choose appropriate metal-connecting nodes and organic-bridging ligands to control the formation of the compounds with required structures and properties. Generally, long chain ligands can lead to large, suitable and well defined voids. Therefore, such ligands are regarded as excellent candidates for the construction of pore structures . For example, Biradha and co-workers reported a nickel compound formulated {[Ni(4,4′-bipyridine)2(NO3)2·2pyrene}n with a 2D network which possesses inner cavities of ca. 8×8Å . By changing 4,4′-bipyridine to a longer ligand 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene, they obtained a nickel compound with bigger square dimensions of 15×15Å . Moreover, according to some recent researches, the interaction between the localized dipoles of the N-containing group and the quadrupole moment of CO2 would induce the dispersion and electrostatic forces to enhance CO2 adsorption and separation abilities on MOFs . Therefore, the long chain ligand 3,6-di-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine (dptz) which contains tetrazine and pyridine functional groups serves as a suitable candidate. The coordination chemistry for these compounds has been studied and some MOFs have been obtained . However, synthesis of robust open frameworks with both high porosity and thermal stability by using ligand (dptz) is scarce. As an extension of our investigation into the chemistry of N-containing heterocyclic MOFs , we used the ligand (dptz) as the bridging ligand to study the properties and the structures of MOFs.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Hydro(solvo)thermal in situ metal/ligand reactions have attracted extensive research interest in coordination and organic chemistry for many decades . This is not only because this method facilitates the synthesis of complexes with beautiful structures and excellent properties, which is not easy for the direct reaction of metal ions and organic ligands, but also because it can be an effective method for preparing organic compounds that are difficult to obtain by the usual routes . In this process, we attempt to introduce metal-connecting nodes at pyridine groups of dptz and to construct metal–organic framework with an appropriate pore structure. However, beyond our expectations, we found an in situ reaction of the ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Hydro(solvo)thermal in situ metal/ligand reactions have attracted extensive research interest in coordination and organic chemistry for many decades . This is not only because this method facilitates the synthesis of complexes with beautiful structures and excellent properties, which is not easy for the direct reaction of metal ions and organic ligands, but also because it can be an effective method for preparing organic compounds that are difficult to obtain by the usual routes . In this process, we attempt to introduce metal-connecting nodes at pyridine groups of dptz and to construct metal–organic framework with an appropriate pore structure. However, beyond our expectations, we found an in situ reaction of the ligand (
).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">In this paper, two new cadmium-organic frameworks, namely [Cd(dptz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·{Cd[(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CS]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}·(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and Cd(dpmtz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), have been synthesized by the reaction of dptz, Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and thiourea in acetonitrile at different reaction temperatures . These compounds were characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses  and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) , as well as TGA measurements . The gas sorption properties have also been studied .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this paper, two new cadmium-organic frameworks, namely [Cd(dptz)2]·{Cd[(NH2)2CS]4}·(NO3)4 (1) and Cd(dpmtz)2 (2), have been synthesized by the reaction of dptz, Cd(SPh)2 and thiourea in acetonitrile at different reaction temperatures . These compounds were characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses  and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) , as well as TGA measurements . The gas sorption properties have also been studied .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The single-crystal X-ray structural analysis indicates that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the tetragonal space group of <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>nbc</ce:italic>. There are two kinds of coordination environments of cadmium atoms in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Cd1 atom is eight-coordinated with hexagonal bipyrimidal geometry formed by four oxygen atoms from two nitrate and four nitrogen atoms from the four different pyridine groups of four dptz ligands, respectively. This means that each Cd1 atom is coordinated by two nitrate and four dptz ligands. The coordination bond lengths of Cd1 atoms and N atoms from dptz ligands are all 2.323(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the angles are 87.35(18)–169.26(18)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°, respectively, as listed in Table S1. The Cd–O distance of Cd1 and O from nitrate is 2.720(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, indicating weak interactions between Cd1 and O from nitrate . On the other hand, each dptz ligand in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> employs its two pyridine groups to connect two metal Cd(II) atoms. Therefore, the coordination interactions between the dptz and Cd(II) atom generate (4,2) connected 2D layered structure (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). These layers form a 3D porous metal–organic framework with interlocked structure via inclined interpenetration (b). However, the void is filled with guest molecules which consist of Cd2 atom and thiourea. The Cd2 atom adopts tetrahedral coordination environment surrounded by four sulfur atoms from four thiourea ligands (Fig. S1). Furthermore, there is NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> within pores to balance the charge of guest molecules which consist of Cd2 atom and thiourea, which further consolidates the framework structure. The guest molecules and NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> make the framework too dense to adsorb any gas molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The single-crystal X-ray structural analysis indicates that compound 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal space group of P42/nbc. There are two kinds of coordination environments of cadmium atoms in 1. Cd1 atom is eight-coordinated with hexagonal bipyrimidal geometry formed by four oxygen atoms from two nitrate and four nitrogen atoms from the four different pyridine groups of four dptz ligands, respectively. This means that each Cd1 atom is coordinated by two nitrate and four dptz ligands. The coordination bond lengths of Cd1 atoms and N atoms from dptz ligands are all 2.323(3)Å and the angles are 87.35(18)–169.26(18)°, respectively, as listed in Table S1. The Cd–O distance of Cd1 and O from nitrate is 2.720(3)Å, indicating weak interactions between Cd1 and O from nitrate . On the other hand, each dptz ligand in 1 employs its two pyridine groups to connect two metal Cd(II) atoms. Therefore, the coordination interactions between the dptz and Cd(II) atom generate (4,2) connected 2D layered structure (a). These layers form a 3D porous metal–organic framework with interlocked structure via inclined interpenetration (b). However, the void is filled with guest molecules which consist of Cd2 atom and thiourea. The Cd2 atom adopts tetrahedral coordination environment surrounded by four sulfur atoms from four thiourea ligands (Fig. S1). Furthermore, there is NO3
− within pores to balance the charge of guest molecules which consist of Cd2 atom and thiourea, which further consolidates the framework structure. The guest molecules and NO3
− make the framework too dense to adsorb any gas molecules.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Based on the similar synthetic system, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be obtained with the only difference of changing the reaction temperature from 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis indicates that <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group of <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, and all the cadmium atoms adopt distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry constructed by two sulfur atoms (S<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and two nitrogen atoms (N<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> and N<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>) from two dpmtz ligands (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The coordination bond lengths and angles around the Cd(II) atom are in the range of 2.276(4)–2.328(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 87.97(10)–124.20(5)°, respectively, as listed in Table S2. Each dpmtz ligand connects two Cd(II) atoms, generating a 3D double interpenetrated framework with 1D pore (Fig. S2), and making the effective pore diameter with 6.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (after considering van der Waals radii). PLATON  analysis reveals that the 3D porous structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is composed of voids of 708<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, which accounts for 22.9% per unit cell volume. To clearly understand the topological structure of the framework, it is necessary to simplify the building units. The Cd atom can be regarded as one node in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. As each Cd is surrounded by two pyridine groups and two mercapto groups, each Cd atom is a 4-connected node. At the same time, the dpmtz ligand can be considered as a linker since it links two Cd atoms. Consequently, according to the calculation of TOPOS , the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> belongs to a 4-connected <ce:italic>dia</ce:italic> type of topology net, with Schläfli symbol of 6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>. Two such nets interpenetrate each other to form a 2-fold interpenetrating framework (b). These results reveal that the difference in reaction temperatures can exert a crucial influence on the structure of the final products.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Based on the similar synthetic system, 2 can be obtained with the only difference of changing the reaction temperature from 100°C to 120°C. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis indicates that 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group of C2/c, and all the cadmium atoms adopt distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry constructed by two sulfur atoms (S1 and S2) and two nitrogen atoms (N5 and N11) from two dpmtz ligands (a). The coordination bond lengths and angles around the Cd(II) atom are in the range of 2.276(4)–2.328(4)Å and 87.97(10)–124.20(5)°, respectively, as listed in Table S2. Each dpmtz ligand connects two Cd(II) atoms, generating a 3D double interpenetrated framework with 1D pore (Fig. S2), and making the effective pore diameter with 6.2Å (after considering van der Waals radii). PLATON  analysis reveals that the 3D porous structure of 2 is composed of voids of 708Å3, which accounts for 22.9% per unit cell volume. To clearly understand the topological structure of the framework, it is necessary to simplify the building units. The Cd atom can be regarded as one node in 2. As each Cd is surrounded by two pyridine groups and two mercapto groups, each Cd atom is a 4-connected node. At the same time, the dpmtz ligand can be considered as a linker since it links two Cd atoms. Consequently, according to the calculation of TOPOS , the framework of 1 belongs to a 4-connected dia type of topology net, with Schläfli symbol of 66. Two such nets interpenetrate each other to form a 2-fold interpenetrating framework (b). These results reveal that the difference in reaction temperatures can exert a crucial influence on the structure of the final products.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The purity of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses, in which each experimental PXRD pattern is well consistent with the one obtained from the stimulated PXRD based on the single crystal samples at room temperature (Fig. S3 and Fig. S4). The thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Fig. S5). Thermal analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable up to 205<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Thermal analysis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows that the weight is almost unchanged in the temperature range of 30–280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Above 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the residue begins to decompose. This means that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is stable up to the high temperature of 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. To verify whether the framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be sustained after activation, PXRD pattern of activated sample was measured (Fig. S4). The framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> still has good crystallinity after this test, and thus gas sorption of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was investigated. Before gas adsorption tests, the activation for removing the guest molecules from the pores by heating under a vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were heated at an optimized temperature of 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The purity of compounds 1 and 2 is confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses, in which each experimental PXRD pattern is well consistent with the one obtained from the stimulated PXRD based on the single crystal samples at room temperature (Fig. S3 and Fig. S4). The thermal stability of 1 and 2 was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Fig. S5). Thermal analysis of 1 shows compound 1 is stable up to 205°C. Thermal analysis of 2 shows that the weight is almost unchanged in the temperature range of 30–280°C. Above 280°C, the residue begins to decompose. This means that compound 2 is stable up to the high temperature of 280°C. To verify whether the framework of 2 can be sustained after activation, PXRD pattern of activated sample was measured (Fig. S4). The framework of 2 still has good crystallinity after this test, and thus gas sorption of 2 was investigated. Before gas adsorption tests, the activation for removing the guest molecules from the pores by heating under a vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples of 2 were heated at an optimized temperature of 100°C for 10h.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherms for activated <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>. The results indicate that the degree of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption (77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) on <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is only minimal, but higher amounts of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) are adsorbed, and the isotherm presents typical type-I curves . The Langmuir and BET surface areas estimated from the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption isotherm are 334 and 239<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, respectively (Fig. S6). The adsorption amount at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm (79<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g) corresponds to 2.29 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules per formula unit. The selective adsorption behaviors of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are ascribed to the fact that larger polarizability and quadrupole moment of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> interact better with the tetrazine and pyridine functional groups, making a contribution to the potential energy of adsorption. Due to very small effective pores, preliminary sorption studies show that desolvated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> does not exhibit N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption property, which is in accordance with single-crystal X-ray analysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms for activated 2 are shown in 
. The results indicate that the degree of N2 adsorption (77K) on 2 is only minimal, but higher amounts of CO2 (195K) are adsorbed, and the isotherm presents typical type-I curves . The Langmuir and BET surface areas estimated from the CO2 sorption isotherm are 334 and 239m2
g−1, respectively (Fig. S6). The adsorption amount at 1atm (79cm3/g) corresponds to 2.29 CO2 molecules per formula unit. The selective adsorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 are ascribed to the fact that larger polarizability and quadrupole moment of CO2 interact better with the tetrazine and pyridine functional groups, making a contribution to the potential energy of adsorption. Due to very small effective pores, preliminary sorption studies show that desolvated 1 does not exhibit N2 adsorption property, which is in accordance with single-crystal X-ray analysis.

gas_adsorption.adsorbed amount: does not exhibit N2 adsorption property

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In summary, two cadmium-organic frameworks have been successfully synthesized by solvothermal reaction at different temperatures. The study reveals that such ligand transformation reaction is highly dependent on temperature of the reaction. In addition, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows selective adsorption behavior of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and it has a 4-connecting double interpenetrated network with the <ce:italic>dia</ce:italic> topology. The results may benefit the research of N-containing ligands and the construction of new MOFs with pore structure and excellent sorption property through solvothermal synthesis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, two cadmium-organic frameworks have been successfully synthesized by solvothermal reaction at different temperatures. The study reveals that such ligand transformation reaction is highly dependent on temperature of the reaction. In addition, compound 2 shows selective adsorption behavior of CO2 over N2, and it has a 4-connecting double interpenetrated network with the dia topology. The results may benefit the research of N-containing ligands and the construction of new MOFs with pore structure and excellent sorption property through solvothermal synthesis.

other properties: selective adsorption behavior of CO2 over N2
4-connecting double interpenetrated network with the dia topology

These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref id="ir0015" xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>. CCDC 956060 and CCDC 956061 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for 1 and 2. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2013.11.011.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: A mixture of 0.51<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol 3,6-di-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine, 0.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, 0.62<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol thiourea and 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml acetonitrile was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), heated at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h. Red block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained in 60% yield (based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): C, 26.91; H, 2.58; N, 26.90. Found: C, 26.94; H, 2.57; N, 26.94. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3387 (m), 3271 (m), 3175 (s), 1613 (s), 1551 (w), 1511 (w), 1476 (m), 1429 (s), 1382 (vs), 1361 (s), 1299 (m), 1210 (m), 1054 (m), 1020 (m), 918(w), 820 (m), 733 (m), 597 (m), 521 (m), 467 (m). Synthesis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: Procedures similar to that for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were performed except that the reaction temperature was changed to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Yellow block crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were isolated after cooling the reaction solution gradually to room temperature and then washed by acetonitrile (yield: 65%, based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) C, 44.41; H, 2.48; N, 25.90. Found: C, 44.38; H, 2.44; N, 25.94. IR (cm<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, KBr): 3415 (m, br), 3102 (w), 3038 (w), 1941 (w), 1611 (s), 1551 (m), 1475 (s), 1453 (s), 1419 (s), 1388 (vs), 1299 (s), 1258 (m), 1218 (m), 1184 (s), 1107 (m), 1073 (s), 1060 (s), 1008 (s), 887 (m), 834 (m), 788 (w), 744 (w), 729 (s), 698 (w), 680 (m), 639 (w), 615 (w), 578 (w), 528 (w), 478 (w).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1: A mixture of 0.51mmol 3,6-di-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine, 0.36mmol Cd(SPh)2, 0.62mmol thiourea and 5ml acetonitrile was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15mL), heated at 100°C for 72h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5°C/h. Red block crystals of 1 were obtained in 60% yield (based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for (1): C, 26.91; H, 2.58; N, 26.90. Found: C, 26.94; H, 2.57; N, 26.94. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3387 (m), 3271 (m), 3175 (s), 1613 (s), 1551 (w), 1511 (w), 1476 (m), 1429 (s), 1382 (vs), 1361 (s), 1299 (m), 1210 (m), 1054 (m), 1020 (m), 918(w), 820 (m), 733 (m), 597 (m), 521 (m), 467 (m). Synthesis of 2: Procedures similar to that for compound 1 were performed except that the reaction temperature was changed to 120°C. Yellow block crystals of 2 were isolated after cooling the reaction solution gradually to room temperature and then washed by acetonitrile (yield: 65%, based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for (2) C, 44.41; H, 2.48; N, 25.90. Found: C, 44.38; H, 2.44; N, 25.94. IR (cm−1, KBr): 3415 (m, br), 3102 (w), 3038 (w), 1941 (w), 1611 (s), 1551 (m), 1475 (s), 1453 (s), 1419 (s), 1388 (vs), 1299 (s), 1258 (m), 1218 (m), 1184 (s), 1107 (m), 1073 (s), 1060 (s), 1008 (s), 887 (m), 834 (m), 788 (w), 744 (w), 729 (s), 698 (w), 680 (m), 639 (w), 615 (w), 578 (w), 528 (w), 478 (w).

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID equipped with a narrow-focus, 5.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kW sealed tube X-ray source (graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation, λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The data processing was accomplished with the PROCESS-AUTO processing program. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was collected on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection, for indexing the reflections, and for determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated by using the SAINT software. All data were collected at a temperature of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Direct methods were used to solve the structure using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were easily found from the difference Fourier map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>r<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1249.82, tetragonal, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4(2)/<ce:italic>nbc</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>24.546(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4629.2(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0502 [<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1435 [all data]. Crystal data for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>CdN<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>r<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>649.01, monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>21.3927(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>24.0819(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15.8047(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, β<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>130.500(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6191.4(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 1 was performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID equipped with a narrow-focus, 5.4kW sealed tube X-ray source (graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation, λ=0.71073Å). The data processing was accomplished with the PROCESS-AUTO processing program. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 2 was collected on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection, for indexing the reflections, and for determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated by using the SAINT software. All data were collected at a temperature of 20±2°C. Direct methods were used to solve the structure using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were easily found from the difference Fourier map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Crystal data for 1: C28H32Cd2N24O12S4, Mr=1249.82, tetragonal, space group P4(2)/nbc, a
=13.7328(19)Å, c
=24.546(5)Å, V
=4629.2(13)Å3, Z
=4, D
c
=1.793g/cm3, GOF=1.055, R

>2σ(I)], wR

=0.1435 [all data]. Crystal data for 2: C24H16CdN12S2, Mr=649.01, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a
=21.3927(6)Å, b
=24.0819(6)Å, c
=15.8047(4)Å, β=130.500(2)°, V
=6191.4(3)Å3, Z
=8, Dc

=1.393g/cm3, GOF=1.101, R

=0.1699 [all data].

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0065" view="all">The phase-purity and crystallinity of each product were checked by PXRD using a Rigaku D/Max2550 automated diffractometer (CuKα, 1.5418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para id="sp0070" view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Netzsch STA 449C instrument. Each sample was heated from room temperature to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a heating rate of 10.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min under nitrogen atmosphere.</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para id="sp0075" view="all">The sorption isotherms for N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K were measured with a Micrometrics ASAP 2010 volumetric gas sorption instrument. Before gas sorption experiments, the as-synthesized samples of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were placed in the quartz tubes and dried under high vacuum at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h to remove the remnant solvent molecules prior to measurements.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
The phase-purity and crystallinity of each product were checked by PXRD using a Rigaku D/Max2550 automated diffractometer (CuKα, 1.5418Å).
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Netzsch STA 449C instrument. Each sample was heated from room temperature to 800°C with a heating rate of 10.0°C/min under nitrogen atmosphere.
The sorption isotherms for N2 and CO2 gas at 77K and 195K were measured with a Micrometrics ASAP 2010 volumetric gas sorption instrument. Before gas sorption experiments, the as-synthesized samples of 2 were placed in the quartz tubes and dried under high vacuum at 100°C for 10h to remove the remnant solvent molecules prior to measurements.

metadata.title: Solvothermal synthesis, structures, and gas adsorption properties of two cadmium-organic frameworks
